metadata.title: Reactive powder concrete reinforced with nano SiO2-coated TiO2

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Reactive powder concrete reinforced with nano SiO2-coated TiO2
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2017.05.065 0950-0618/ 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: hithanbaoguo@163.com, hanbaoguo@dlut.edu.cn (B. Han).
Baoguo Han a,⇑, Zhen Li a, Liqing Zhang a, Shuzhu Zeng a, Xun Yu b,c, Bing Han a, Jinping Ou c,d a School of Civil Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China bDepartment of Mechanical Engineering, New York Institute of Technology, New York, NY 11568, USA c School of Mechanical Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430081, China d School of Civil Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150090, China
h i g h l i g h t s
Nano SiO2-coated TiO2 is used to reinforce reactive powder concrete (RPC). Inclusion of nano SiO2-coated TiO2 into RPC leads to increase of 87%/6.69 MPa in flexural strength. Nano SiO2-coated TiO2 has pozzolanic effect and decreases the amount of CH. Coating of nano SiO2 at surface of TiO2 is beneficial for dispersion of nano fillers in matrix.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 10 March 2017 Received in revised form 28 April 2017 Accepted 6 May 2017
Keywords: Reactive powder concrete SiO2-coated TiO2 Mechanical behavior Microstructural analysis
a b s t r a c t
Nano SiO2-coated TiO2 (NSCT) is used to reinforce reactive powder concrete (RPC). The reinforcing mechanisms of NSCT are investigated through thermogravimetry (TG) analysis, X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis, elemental analysis and scanning electron microscope (SEM) observation. The mechanical strengths of the NSCT reinforced RPC (NSCTRRPC) at different curing ages manifest significant increases, especially flexural behaviors. The flexural and compressive strengths of NSCTRRPC at age of 28 d achieve increases of 87%/6.69 MPa and 12.26%/12.2 MPa with respect to RPC without NSCT, respectively. TG analyses suggest that acceleration of cement hydration caused by nucleus effect plays a dominant role in the early days. XRD analyses manifests the NSCT decreases the amount of CH crystals in matrix. This suggests that the NSCT has the pozzolanic effect. In addition, element analysis is indicative that NSCT is uniformly distributed inside the matrix to make the cement matrix more compact, which is in consistent with SEM observations. It is therefore concluded that coating of nano SiO2 at the surface of TiO2 is beneficial for the dispersion of nano fillers in matrix and the pozzolanic effect, thus modifying the microstructures and the mechanical property of RPC.
2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As a kind of building materials, cement-based material is widely used in the field of civil engineering due to its advantages of high compressive strength, low-cost preparation, simple preparation method and convenient usage. However, the disadvantages of
low tensile strain and fracture toughness make this kind of material fail to satisfy some special environmental needs with the rapid development of modern society. Thereby, new cement-based composite with high strength, high fracture toughness and high durability is in urgent need.
It has been confirmed that nano-TiO2 (NT) can improve the mechanical properties of cement-based composites like strength and fracture toughness due to the nucleation effect and filling effect [1–4]. Nazari et al. [5] studied the flexural strength of
Table 1 Properties of NSCT.
SiO2/TiO2 ratio Diameter of NSCT/nm Crystal form of TiO2
0.04 20 Rutile phase
Fig. 1. SEM image of NSCT (100,000 ).
concrete with four different contents of 0.5%, 0.1%, 1.5% and 2.0% NT by cement weight. They observed that the flexural strengths of concrete were enhanced by increasing the NT content. The optimal amount of NT is 2 wt%, which leads to increases in flexural strength of 25%/1.1 MPa at curing age of 28 d. Jalal et al. [6] fabricated concrete with up to 5 wt% of NT. They observed that the compressive strength of NT filled concrete at curing age of 28 d was higher than that of the concrete without NT. The maximum increase in compressive strength is 22.12%/11.5 MPa. They stated that the NT can increase crystalline CH amount at the early age of hydration and accelerate C–S–H gel formation, hence it can increase the strength of the cement. However, due to the large specific surface area and unsaturated bond, the agglomerate of NT is formed easily [7–12]. For this reason, there are certain defects at the binding interface between the concrete and NT. Therefore, the improving efficiency of concrete strength is limited.
In recently years, the nanotechnology has been developing rapidly with the continuous improvement of the preparation and characterization of solid materials [13–21]. As the size of solid materials decreased, the specific surface area of the solid materials increased. The performance and application of the solid materials would be influenced by the surface texture and electronic properties seriously when their sizes decreased to the nano range. In this case, modifying the interface of NT by coating with nano sized SiO2 is carried out. Ti-O-Si bonds can be formed at the NT interface through this method [22– 25]. This type of chemical bonds can bring more negative charges at the surface of NT which are conducive to its dispersion in water by the reaction of electrostatic repulsion. However, previous studies [26–30] mainly focus on the dispersion in the solution and the photocatalysis properties of SiO2coated TiO2 (NSCT). The research on the effect of adding NSCT into the concrete has not been done. Furthermore, some researches indicated that SiO2 can enhance the mechanical properties of concrete for its pozzolanic effect [31–35]. In other words, the SiO2, which coated at the surface of the NT for better dispersion in the solution, may act synergistically with NT to improve the performance of concrete. The reactive powder concrete (RPC) is developed by a French laboratory in the 1990s. It is a kind of high-performance concrete with the advantages of high-tensile, high-toughness and excellent highdurability. To take RPC in lieu of traditional concrete can not only reduce the amount of reinforcing steel bars and the weight of the structure, but also increase the strength and the life of the structure. If NSCT can further improve the mechanical behaviors of RPC, it would reap huge fruits in civil engineering.
Based on the above analysis, different contents of NSCT were introduced to prepare NSCT reinforced RPC (NSCTRRPC) in this study. Their flexural and compressive properties at curing age of 3 d and 28 d are investigated. Several methods includes thermogravimetry (TG) analysis, X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis, elemental analysis and scanning electron microscope (SEM) observation are carried out to explore the underlying reinforcing mechanisms of NSCT to RPC.

sections.heading: 2.1. Raw material and mix proportion
sections.text:
The Portland cement (OPC 42.5R) produced by Dalian Onoda Cement Co. Ltd. in China was used in this study. The NSCT produced by Nanjing Hai Tai Nano Materials Co. Ltd. in China was applied. The NSCT is rutile phase TiO2 which is coated by SiO2. The SiO2 to TiO2 ratio is about 0.04. The main properties of NSCT are shown in Table 1. The SEM image of NSCT is shown in Fig. 1.
Silica fume is a commercially available product of Shanghai Elkem International Trade Co. Ltd. in China. The fly ash provided by Dalian Daokete Building Materials Co. Ltd. in China was used. Quartz sand with a size range of 0.12–0.83 mm was used as aggregate. The SiO2 and Fe2O3 content of quartz sand is more than 99–99.5% and less than 0.005%, respectively. RHEOPLUS 411 (BASF) was used as a superplasticizer (PC) to adjust the workability of the composite mixtures.
The ratio of cement (C), quartz sand (QS), silica fume (SF), water (W) was equal to 1:1.1:0.25:0.3. The content of superplasticizer (SP) was adjusted according to the amount of NSCT, ensuring that the composite mixture can be easily molded and there is no bleeding after vibration. The NSCT was added in the amount of 0%, 1.0%, 3.0% and 5.0% by cement weight. The NSCTRRPC with different content of NSCT was marked as T0, T1, T3, T5, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Specimen preparation
sections.text:
The cement mortar mixer was used to stir NSCTRRPC, at low speed of 140 ± 5 r/min and high speed of 285 ± 10 r/min. The process of fabricating NSCTRRPC is as follows: (1) Water, NSCT, and cement were put into mixing pans together, stirring for 20 s at low speed. Then silica fume was put into pans, stirring for 60 s at low speed. And then cement and fly ash were put into pans, stirring for 2 min at low speed and 2 min at high speed separately. (2) Quartz sand was put into the slurry, stirring for 1 min at low speed and 4 min at high speed separately. The mixture was poured into the oiled mould (40 mm 40 mm 160 mm) and then the mold was put on the electric vibrator in order to eliminate bubbles. (3) All cement mortars were cured at a temperature of 20.0 C in 95% relative humidity for 24 h before demolding. Then specimens were cured in water at 20 ± 1 C until the curing age was arrived at the age of 3 d and 28 d.
The samples for TG and XRD test were cement paste because sand may affect the degree of accuracy of results. The weight of dry sand does not decrease with increasing temperatures, and the amount of sand in samples for TG is random. Beyond that, the XRD characteristic peaks of sand are too strong which would make the XRD peaks of hydration products of cement unobservable. The NSCT was added in the amount of 0%, 1.0%, 3.0% and 5.0% by cement weight. The cement paste with NSCT was marked as PT0, PT1, PT3, PT5. The manufacture process of cement paste was the same with the NSCTRRPC except that the process of adding sand was not need. After hydration for 3 d and 28 d, the cement pastes was crushed, milled, and sieved at 80 mm for XRD test. In addition, samples were dried at 40 C for 24 h to avoid the effect of absorbed water. The samples for elemental analysis and SEM analysis were selected from the NSCTRRPC after testing flexural and compressive strength at the age of 28 d.

sections.heading: 2.3. Measurement
sections.text:
The tests of specimens included flexural strength, compressive strength and microanalysis. The flexural strength was measured by universal electronic testing machine (WDW-200E, Jinan Times Shi Jin Test Machine Co., Ltd) according to (Method of testing cements determination of strength-ISO) GB/T17671-1999 of China. The loading rate was 0.05 mm/min. Compressive strength was also tested by WDW-200E at the curing age of 3 d and 28 d. The loading rate was 1.2 mm/min. Dimension of the specimens and the schematic diagrams of loading regime are shown in Fig. 2. The average value of flexural and compressive strengths of three specimens in each group was regarded as the final results in every curing age if the difference between average and the maximum and the minimum compressive strength was less than 10%. TG analysis was performed using a METTLER TOLEDO STARe system to get the amount of CH and other hydration products. The condition of TG analysis was under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 C/min up to 1000 C under flowing nitrogen (at the 105 C and 1000 C each stay for two hours). XRD (Bruker D8 Advance, Bruker German) was applied for studying the change tendency of crystal of calcium hydroxide which was caused by NT coated by SiO2. Field emission scanning electron microscope (Nova Nano SEM 450, American FEI Ltd.) was used to carry out elemental analysis and SEM analysis.

sections.heading: 3.1. Flexural behaviors
sections.text:
The flexural strengths of NSCTRRPC at curing age of 3 d and 28 d are demonstrated in Fig. 3. The relative increase rates of NSCTRRPC with respect to plain RPC in flexural strength at curing age of 3 d and 28 d have been marked in the Figure.
It can be indicated from Fig. 3 that the flexural strength of NSCTRRPC at 3 d increased firstly and then decreased slightly as the content of NSCT increased. When the content of NSCT was 3%, flexural strength of NSCTRRPC reached its maximum 9.77 MPa and increased 83.3%/4.44 MPa with respect to that of RPC without NSCT. When the NSCT content was 5%, the flexural strength of NSCTRRPC was still much higher than plain RPC, even although it was a little bit lower than that with 3% content of NSCT. As for the increase in flexural strength at 3 days when using 5% of NSCT is less than the increase achieved with 3% of NSCT. It may be attributed to a reduction in hydration speed due to water absorption. The flexural strength of NSCTRRPC at 28 d increased with increasing content of NSCT. The optimal level of NSCT content was achieved at 5.0% at the age of 28 d. The flexural strength was 14.38 MPa and improved 87%/6.69 MPa relatively to that of RPC without NSCT. This means that NSCT can not only improve flexural strength effectively at early age (3 d), but also at later age (28 d).

sections.heading: 3.2. Compressive behaviors
sections.text:
The compressive strengths of NSCTRRPC at 3 d and 28 d are demonstrated in Fig. 4. The relative increase rates of NSCTRRPC with respect to plain RPC in compressive strength at curing age of 3 d and 28 d have been marked in the Figure.
As indicated in Fig. 4, the presence of NSCT has no obvious effect on the compressive strength of the composites at the curing age of 3 d, but it has obvious impact on that at the curing age of 28 d. For the NSCTRRPC at 28 d, the compressive strength reached its maximum 111.75 MPa and increased 12.26%/12.2 MPa compared with the plain RPC. This can be attributed to that NSCT bring more negative charges on the surface of NT which are conducive to its dispersion in water by the reaction of electrostatic repulsion. In addition, the reaction between SiO2 coated at the surface of TiO2 and CH, which is called pozzolanic reaction, and it can promote
cm

schematic diagrams of loading regime.
the hydration reaction to gain more hydration products, reducing the negative influence for matrix strength by CH as shown in Fig. 5. What’s more, the adsorption of NT is quite effective. The SiO2 coated at the surface of NT can react with CH while hydration products are formed on surface which can promote nucleation effect, filling effect, increasing the degree of cement density and decrease the number of harmful holes.
As manifested in Fig. 6, the RPC became denser and denser with the increasing content of NSCT, consequently the mechanical property of NSCTRRPC can be enhanced with the increasing content of NSCT. The improvement rates of compressive strength were much less than that of flexural strength for the same test specimens. It is due to the NSCT can improve the toughness of the RPC significantly. Three factors may work together for contribution to the
pozzolanic effect of NSCT.
effect: (1) the NSCT dispersed in the matrix can improve the density of the matrix which is beneficial to improve the fracture toughness of the composites; (2) the addition of NSCT can inhibit the size of the CH crystal, thus resulting in more interfaces. This can make the cracks along the crystal fracture path become more tortuous; (3) NSCT has the nano-core effect which can inhibit the expansion of cracks to achieve the effect of toughening by making the cracks go through the crystal or occur deflection (as shown in Fig. 7).

sections.heading: 3.3. TG analysis
sections.text:
The TG and DTG curves for the cement paste with different amounts of NSCT are presented in Figs. 8 and 9, respectively. It is shown in the DTG curves that there were three obvious peaks of the 1st derivative of mass of cement paste round the temperature of 105, 450 and 750. These peaks should be attributed to the evaporation of physically bonded water, decomposition of CH and decomposition of CaCO3, respectively. The hydration degree of the cement can be obtained on account of Eqs. (1) and (2).
M0Water ¼ M105 M1000 MCaCO3 ð1Þ
bt ¼ M0water=ðMwater Full rÞ ð2Þ where bt represents cement hydration degree, M 0 Water is the mass of non-evaporable water (g), M105 and M1000 are the mass loss of cement paste in 105 C and 1000 C, respectively (g). MCaCO3
represents the mass loss of cement paste due to the decomposition of CaCO3 during heating (g). MWater Full is the water required for the full hydration of cement (g), r represents the cement to binder ratio [36]. According to Ref. [37], the water required is 0.23 g for full hydration of 1 g cement. The ratios of cement to binder of PT0, PT1, PT3 and PT5 in this paper are 0.64, 0.63, 0.62 and 0.61, respectively. The cement hydration degree at curing age of 3 d and 28 d are list in Table 2. It can be seen from Table 2 that the cement hydration degree increased as NSCT content increasing, especially at 3 d. When the content of NSCT was 5%, the cement hydration enhanced 5.2% with respect to cement paste without NSCT. However, the cement hydration degree was almost the same at 28 d. It suggested that acceleration of hydration caused by nucleus effect plays a dominant role in the early days.

sections.heading: 3.4. XRD analysis
sections.text:
The influence of NSCT on CH orientation in the matrix can be determined by XRD as manifested in Fig. 10. The XRD pattern of PT0, PT1, PT3, PT5 at curing age of 3 d and 28 d were shown in that. It can be seen that the intensity of main diffraction peaks of CH in PT1, PT3, PT5 were all lower than those in PT0 no matter at curing age of 3 d or at the age of 28 d, and the intensity of main diffraction peaks decreased as the content of NSCT increased. It is known from Ref. [38] that the diffraction peak intensity of a certain crystal phase increases with the increasing relative content. Moreover, the CH crystal is a major crystal phase in the cement paste.
on the micro-crack extend.
Therefore we can come to the conclusion that the relative content of CH is reduced with the increasing content of NSCT. This can be attributed to the SiO2 coated on the NT has the pozzolanic effect and consumed some CH.
In addition, (001) and (101) crystal face peak intensity of CH can be obtained and then the CH orientation can be calculated according to the calculation given in Ref. [39]. The orientation index in is defined as R. R can be obtained on account of Eq. (3).
R ¼ 1:35Ið001Þ=Ið101Þ ð3Þ Where Ið001Þ and Ið101Þ is (001) and (101) crystal face peak intensity, respectively. The results are shown in Table 3. The orientation index of CH decreased with the increasing content of NSCT. At 3 d, the indexes of CH in PT0, PT1, PT3 and PT5 are 2.62, 2.46. 2.11. 1.44, respectively. At 28 d, the indexes of CH in PT0, PT1, PT3 and PT5 are 1.77, 1.55, 1.57, 1.47, respectively. The results reveal that NSCT can decrease the orientation of CH crystals in matrix.

sections.heading: 3.5. Elemental analysis
sections.text: The distribution of NSCT in cement paste was in good order as manifested in Fig. 11 and there were no obvious phenomena of aggregation. It is mainly because that the interface of TiO2 modified by SiO2 can make Ti-O-Si bond, making the NT with more negative charges which are conducive to disperse in matrix as shown in Fig. 12. Therefore, the filling effect of NSCT for the cement paste increased with the increasing content of the NSCT. Hence, NSCT can make cement matrices more compact, enhancing the flexural and compressive strength of the NSCTRRPC.

sections.heading: 3.6. SEM analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 13 shows the CH crystals particle size decreased with the increasing content of NSCT. It is mainly because that the pozzolanic
reaction occurred between SiO2 wrapped at the surface of TiO2 and the CH. This reaction can consume a part of CH, promote the hydration reaction, generate more C-S-H, hence making the matrix more compact. In addition, The C-S-H formed by pozzolanic reaction
adhered to the surface of TiO2, making the nucleation reaction happen. It can also enhance the matrix density degree. Thereby, CH crystals are refined, and the matrix becomes more and more compact.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
NSCT was explored as filler to modify RPC. The effect of different contents of NSCT to mechanical properties of NSCTRRPC was investigated. In general, the mechanical properties of NSCTRRPC are superior to that of RPC without NSCT.
The flexural and compressive behaviors of NSCTRRPC have been improved significantly due to the addition of NSCT. When the content of NSCT was up to 5%, the flexural strength of NSCTRRPC at 28 d reached its maximum 14.38 MPa and increased 87%/6.69 MPa compared to that of RPC without NSCT. The compressive strength of NSCTRRPC maintained a higher growth rate at later age than that at early age. With 3% content of NSCT, 28 d compressive strength reached its maximum 111.75 MPa and increased 12.26%/12.2 MPa with respect to plain RPC. NSCT could accelerate the hydration process of NSCTRRPC, especially at 3 d. It suggested that acceleration of hydration caused by nucleus effect plays a leading role in the early age. However, due to the NSCT has the characteristic of high specific surface area and strong water imbibition, NSCT could absorb some water which would harm the hydration of cement. This is the reason for the compressive strengths of RPC with 5% content of NSCT is less than that with 3% content of NSCT at curing age of 28 d. Comprehensive consideration of the workability of the NSCTRRPC, the optimum content of NSCT is around 3%. The distribution of NSCT in NSCTRRPC was in good order and there were no obvious phenomena of aggregation.
It is mainly because that the interface of TiO2 modified by SiO2 can form Ti-O-Si bonds at the TiO2 interface, make the TiO2 molecule with more negative charges which are conducive to disperse in matrix. What’s more, the number of NSCT in the distribution diagram increased with the increasing content of NSCT. It also illustrated that the filling effect of NSCT for RPC increased with the increasing content of the NSCT. In addition, NSCT can decrease the mount and the tendency of crystals of CH in cement matrix which is helpful to strength promotion.
NSCT can obviously enhance the mechanical properties and modify microstructures of RPC. It can not only decrease the CH crystals size, but also can react with CH resulting in formation of more C-S-H and denser matrix and reduction of amount of free CH. Therefore, it is an effective filler to modify the compressive and flexural properties of RPC, thus developing high-performance concrete with high strength and durability.

(2) Quartz sand was put into the slurry, stirring for 1 min at low speed and 4 min at high speed separately.

effect: (1) the NSCT dispersed in the matrix can improve the density of the matrix which is beneficial to improve the fracture toughness of the composites; (2) the addition of NSCT can inhibit the size of the CH crystal, thus resulting in more interfaces.

effect: (1) the NSCT dispersed in the matrix can improve the density of the matrix which is beneficial to improve the fracture toughness of the composites; (2) the addition of NSCT can inhibit the size of the CH crystal, thus resulting in more interfaces.
